block.p: China Warns of Arms Race If U.S. Builds Missile Shield China's chief arms negotiator, Sha Zukang, said the American proposal to build an antimissile defensive shield posed an unacceptable threat to China's security and could force Beijing to expand its own nuclear forces.

China Warns of Arms Race If U.S. Builds Missile Shield China's chief arms negotiator, Sha Zukang, said the American proposal to build an antimissile defensive shield posed an unacceptable threat to China's security and could force Beijing to expand its own nuclear forces.
The Pentagon is assessing whether the United States can safely cut its nuclear arsenal to 2,000 warheads under a treaty with Russia.
U.N. Troops Prepare for Battle The United Nations ordered its peacekeeping troops in Sierra Leone to take up defensive positions and prepare to fight rebels advancing toward the capital, Freetown.
Thousands of people fleeing the fighting headed toward Freetown. The whereabouts of a rebel leader, Foday Sankoh, remained unclear.
Africa Allies at Odds Rwanda and Uganda are threatening to turn their armies on each other if they cannot resolve the tensions that in recent days have flared up into small-scale skirmishes.
U.N. Fails in Horn of Africa A Security Council delegation ended a weeklong trip to Africa unable to persuade the leaders of Eritrea and Ethiopia to stop preparing for war and to resume talks.

More AIDS Drugs for Africa President Clinton ignored opposition from the pharmaceutical industry and issued an executive order to make AIDS drugs available far more cheaply in sub-Saharan Africa by easing patent restrictions.

New Russian Prime Minister President Vladimir V. Putin named as prime minister Mikhail M. Kasyanov, a chief foreign-debt negotiator and a liberal economics expert. Some experts said the move boded well for efforts to tame Russia's freewheeling style of capitalism.

Lawyer Says Jew Denies Spying One of 13 Iranian Jews being tried on charges of spying for Israel denied all accusations, a defense lawyer said, becoming the first of the group not to confess in court.

Army Inquiry Said to Back Officer's Harassment Claim The inspector general has concluded that the Army's highest-ranking woman, Lt. Gen. Claudia J. Kennedy, was a victim of inappropriate sexual advances by Gen. Larry G. Smith, Pentagon officials said.

A Flag Plan in South Carolina The House passed a measure that would take down the Confederate flag from atop the Capitol on July 1 and raise a smaller version at a nearby Confederate soldiers' memorial. The Senate has passed a similar measure. The governor said he backed the plan. But only 3 of the 26 black House members voted for the plan, and many denounced it.

Fire Bears Down on Nuclear Lab Winds blew a week-old fire toward the Los Alamos National Laboratory, forcing the evacuation of the town of Los Alamos, but officials expressed confidence that nuclear materials and chemical explosives at the lab were safe and protected.

U.S. Replacing Prosecutor The Justice Department has decided to replace Bob Gorence as the top prosecutor in the case against Wen Ho Lee, a scientist charged with mishandling nuclear weapon secrets at the Los Alamos National Laboratory. No explanation was given.

State Dept. Faulted on Security The State Department suffers from a systemic failure to protect secrets that is longstanding and far broader than the recent disclosed series of lapses, according to a range of administration officials.
2 Winners of Record Jackpot Two winning tickets, one in Michigan and one in Illinois, were sold in the $366 million Big Game drawing.
No Bar to Saline Implants The F.D.A. decided to permit two implant makers to continue marketing saline breast implants, despite new scientific evidence that some patients had had adverse effects.
U.S. to Test H.I.V. Drug The National Institutes of Health is set to begin full-scale tests of Remune, a vaccine to treat people already infected with H.I.V..

Giuliani and Hanover Talk About a Separation Mayor Giuliani said he was seeking a separation from his wife, Donna Hanover, adding that as he battled prostate cancer he would need Judith Nathan, whom he describes as a ''very good'' friend, ''more now than maybe I did before.'' Ms. Hanover said that she had hoped to keep the marriage together but that she was now prepared to ''discuss the possibility of a legal separation.'' She also said she had withdrawn from the couple's public life several years ago ''because of his relationship with one staff member.'' An aide said she was referring to the mayor's former communications director, Cristyne Lategano-Nicholas.
Representative Rick A. Lazio and Theodore J. Forstmann, a Wall Street investor, moved gingerly to position themselves in case Mr. Giuliani leaves the Senate race.

Welfare Contract Questioned A top city welfare official agreed to pay the Kaiser Group of Wisconsin $1.1 million for consulting services it provided last year, despite the absence of a written contract and competitive bidding. Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi said the arrangement violated standard procedures.
Woman Killed on Queens Street A 24-year-old Japanese woman who worked as a music promoter was fatally shot about 3:15 a.m. as she walked home on a quiet street in Elmhurst, the police said.

New Jersey Race Narrowing A poll suggested that Jon S. Corzine's million-dollar-a-week television advertising campaign was narrowing his race with former Gov. Jim Florio for the Democratic Senate nomination and driving up Mr. Florio's unfavorable ratings. The candidates are scheduled to debate tonight.

Ruling on Access to Public Land A Connecticut appeals court said Greenwich could no longer bar out-of-towners from its parks and beaches. Lawyers on both sides said the ruling could affect public access throughout the state.

Microsoft's Counterplan Microsoft asked a federal judge to immediately throw out the government's proposal to break the company in two. It offered a series of proposals that it said were more appropriate than a breakup.

Music Antitrust Case Settled The F.T.C. announced a settlement of an antitrust case against the five largest music companies in the nation. Officials said a result should be significant price cuts for CD's.
Scrutiny of Accountants Urged The S.E.C. chairman, Arthur Levitt, called for more oversight and new rules on conflicts of interest at accounting firms, to preserve integrity in financial reporting.

Auction House Intervenes EBay canceled the sale of an abstract painting to a Dutch computer executive for $135,805, saying the seller, Kenneth A. Walton, had violated its rules in a way that artificially inflated the price.
Editorials: Mr. Giuliani's turbulent time; moms marching for gun control; a weak but crafty Microsoft. Columns: Bob Herbert, William Safire.
